title: Welcome!
text:
I am a graduate student in biological sciences at Cal Poly Pomona.
I have a background in bee biology, biological monitoring and plant identification, ecological restoration, and environmental education. I am currently studying the foraging behavior of squash bees in farms in Southern California.



Above: male squash bees in a pumpkin flower

title: About This Website
text:
I am a graduate student in biological sciences at Cal Poly Pomona. This website contains information about my past work and current research interests.



Above: native sweat bees on common rush (Juncus patens)

title: Research Interests
text:
My research interests involve bee-plant interactions, specifically those involving solitary specialist bees. I am especially interested in how solitary bees are interacting with economically important crops. Squash bees, the main native pollinators of squash, pumpkin, and gourds, have been widely studied, but not much is known about the floral sex preferences of male and female bees visiting squash flowers. For my thesis research, I hope to better understand if squash bee foraging behavior changes seasonally, and if male and female bees have a preference for visiting male or female squash flowers.



Above: male squash bee in pumpkin flower

title: Bio
text:
I am currently a graduate student at Cal Poly Pomona studying squash bee foraging behavior in Southern California.
For several years before starting graduate school, my work involved ecological restoration in riparian and oak woodland ecosystems in the San Francisco Bay Area. I have also led interpretive hikes, and worked with students (pre-K to adult) in outdoor and classroom settings.



Above: a predatory snakefly at a past restoration site.





Above: a forest scorpion under UV light seen during a night hike in the Santa Cruz mountains.

title: Contact
text:
If you have questions about my research, you can reach me at switt@cpp.edu.



Above: small native bee on rare Franciscan onion (Allium peninsulare var. franciscanum)
